questions.explanation: The frequency response H(ω) is the Fourier transform of the impulse response h(t). It describes how the system modifies each frequency component. Every LTI system has a unique frequency response.

questions.prompt: If input is X(ω), output is:
questions.explanation: For LTI systems: Y(ω) = X(ω)·H(ω). Each frequency is scaled by H at that frequency. This is the frequency-domain equivalent of convolution y = x*h. Much simpler computation.
The magnitude response |H(ω)| shows how much the system amplifies or attenuates each frequency. Values |H|>1 mean gain, |H|<1 mean attenuation. Key for filter design.
The phase response ∠H(ω) shows phase shift applied to each frequency. Linear phase means constant delay. Nonlinear phase causes dispersion—different frequencies arrive at different times.

Low-pass filters pass low frequencies (|H|≈1) and attenuate high frequencies (|H|→0). Applications: smoothing, noise reduction, anti-aliasing before sampling. Most practical signals need low-pass filtering.
High-pass filters block DC and low frequencies while passing high frequencies. Applications: removing DC offset, edge detection, AC coupling. The dual of low-pass filtering.

questions.prompt: The cutoff frequency ωc is where |H(ωc)| =:
questions.explanation: Cutoff frequency is the -3dB point where |H| = 1/√2 ≈ 0.707. Power is halved at this frequency. This is the conventional boundary between passband and stopband for analog filters.
Bandwidth is usually measured as the frequency range where |H| ≥ 1/√2 (within 3dB of peak). For low-pass: BW = ωc. For bandpass: BW = ω₂-ω₁. Wider BW means faster potential response.
Bandpass filters pass frequencies in a specific band [ω₁,ω₂] and attenuate outside. Applications: radio tuning, voice extraction, frequency selection. Center frequency = (ω₁+ω₂)/2.
Group delay τg = -dφ/dω is the negative derivative of phase. It measures the delay of the signal envelope at each frequency. Constant group delay means no dispersion—signal shape preserved.
